t: Exodus 1
Now*p these are the names of the children of Israel, which came into Egypt; every man and his household came with Jacob.
Reuben,*p Simeon, Levi, and Judah,
Issachar,*p Zebulun, and Benjamin,
Dan,*p and Naphtali, Gad, and Asher.
And*p all the souls that came out of the loins of Jacob were seventy souls: for Joseph was in Egypt already.
And*p Joseph died, and all his brethren, and all that generation.
And*p the children of Israel were fruitful, and increased abundantly, and multiplied, and waxed exceeding mighty; and the land was filled with them.
Now*p there arose up a new king over Egypt, which knew not Joseph.
And*p he said unto his people, Behold, the people of the children of Israel are more and mightier than we:

Come*p on, let us deal wisely with them; lest they multiply, and it come to pass, that, when there falleth out any war, they join also unto our enemies, and fight against us, and so get them up out of the land.
Therefore*p they did set over them taskmasters to afflict them with their burdens. And they built for Pharaoh treasure cities, Pithom and Rameses.
But*p the more they afflicted them, the more they multiplied and grew. And they were grieved because of the children of Israel.
And*p the Egyptians made the children of Israel to serve with rigour:
And*p they made their lives bitter with hard bondage, in mortar, and in brick, and in all manner of service in the field: all their service, wherein they made them serve, was with rigour.
And*p the king of Egypt spake to the Hebrew midwives, of which the name of the one was Shiphrah, and the name of the other Puah:
And*p he said, When ye do the office of a midwife to the Hebrew women, and see them upon the stools; if it be a son, then ye shall kill him: but if it be a daughter, then she shall live.
But*p the midwives feared God, and did not as the king of Egypt commanded them, but saved the men children alive.
And*p the king of Egypt called for the midwives, and said unto them, Why have ye done this thing, and have saved the men children alive?
And*p the midwives said unto Pharaoh, Because the Hebrew women are not as the Egyptian women; for they are lively, and are delivered ere the midwives come in unto them.
Therefore*p God dealt well with the midwives: and the people multiplied, and waxed very mighty.
And*p it came to pass, because the midwives feared God, that he made them houses.
And*p Pharaoh charged all his people, saying, Every son that is born ye shall cast into the river, and every daughter ye shall save alive.
Exodus 2
And*p there went a man of the house of Levi, and took to wife a daughter of Levi.
And*p the woman conceived, and bare a son: and when she saw him that he was a goodly child, she hid him three months.
And*p when she could not longer hide him, she took for him an ark of bulrushes, and daubed it with slime and with pitch, and put the child therein; and she laid it in the flags by the river's brink.
And*p his sister stood afar off, to wit what would be done to him.
And*p the daughter of Pharaoh came down to wash herself at the river; and her maidens walked along by the river's side; and when she saw the ark among the flags, she sent her maid to fetch it.
And*p when she had opened it, she saw the child: and, behold, the babe wept. And she had compassion on him, and said, This is one of the Hebrews' children.
Then*p said his sister to Pharaoh's daughter, Shall I go and call to thee a nurse of the Hebrew women, that she may nurse the child for thee?
And*p Pharaoh's daughter said to her, Go. And the maid went and called the child's mother.
And*p Pharaoh's daughter said unto her, Take this child away, and nurse it for me, and I will give thee thy wages. And the woman took the child, and nursed it.
And*p the child grew, and she brought him unto Pharaoh's daughter, and he became her son. And she called his name Moses: and she said, Because I drew him out of the water.
And*p it came to pass in those days, when Moses was grown, that he went out unto his brethren, and looked on their burdens: and he spied an Egyptian smiting an Hebrew, one of his brethren.
And*p he looked this way and that way, and when he saw that there was no man, he slew the Egyptian, and hid him in the sand.
And*p when he went out the second day, behold, two men of the Hebrews strove together: and he said to him that did the wrong, Wherefore smitest thou thy fellow?
And*p he said, Who made thee a prince and a judge over us? intendest thou to kill me, as thou killedst the Egyptian? And Moses feared, and said, Surely this thing is known.
Now*p when Pharaoh heard this thing, he sought to slay Moses. But Moses fled from the face of Pharaoh, and dwelt in the land of Midian: and he sat down by a well.
Now*p the priest of Midian had seven daughters: and they came and drew water, and filled the troughs to water their father's flock.
And*p the shepherds came and drove them away: but Moses stood up and helped them, and watered their flock.
And*p when they came to Reuel their father, he said, How is it that ye are come so soon to day?
And*p they said, An Egyptian delivered us out of the hand of the shepherds, and also drew water enough for us, and watered the flock.
And*p he said unto his daughters, And where is he? why is it that ye have left the man? call him, that he may eat bread.
And*p Moses was content to dwell with the man: and he gave Moses Zipporah his daughter.
And*p she bare him a son, and he called his name Gershom: for he said, I have been a stranger in a strange land.

And*p it came to pass in process of time, that the king of Egypt died: and the children of Israel sighed by reason of the bondage, and they cried, and their cry came up unto God by reason of the bondage.
And*p God heard their groaning, and God remembered his covenant with Abraham, with Isaac, and with Jacob.
And*p God looked upon the children of Israel, and God had respect unto them.
Exodus 3
Now*p Moses kept the flock of Jethro his father in law, the priest of Midian: and he led the flock to the backside of the desert, and came to the mountain of God, even to Horeb.
And*p the angel of the Lord*s appeared unto him in a flame of fire out of the midst of a bush: and he looked, and, behold, the bush burned with fire, and the bush was not consumed.
And*p Moses said, I will now turn aside, and see this great sight, why the bush is not burnt.
And*p when the Lord*s saw that he turned aside to see, God called unto him out of the midst of the bush, and said, Moses, Moses. And he said, Here am I.
And*p he said, Draw not nigh hither: put off thy shoes from off thy feet, for the place whereon thou standest is holy ground.
Moreover*p he said, I am the God of thy father, the God of Abraham, the God of Isaac, and the God of Jacob. And Moses hid his face; for he was afraid to look upon God.
And*p the Lord*s said, I have surely seen the affliction of my people which are in Egypt, and have heard their cry by reason of their taskmasters; for I know their sorrows;

And*p I am come down to deliver them out of the hand of the Egyptians, and to bring them up out of that land unto a good land and a large, unto a land flowing with milk and honey; unto the place of the Canaanites, and the Hittites, and the Amorites, and the Perizzites, and the Hivites, and the Jebusites.
Now*p therefore, behold, the cry of the children of Israel is come unto me: and I have also seen the oppression wherewith the Egyptians oppress them.
Come*p now therefore, and I will send thee unto Pharaoh, that thou mayest bring forth my people the children of Israel out of Egypt.
And*p Moses said unto God, Who am I, that I should go unto Pharaoh, and that I should bring forth the children of Israel out of Egypt?
And*p he said, Certainly I will be with thee; and this shall be a token unto thee, that I have sent thee: When thou hast brought forth the people out of Egypt, ye shall serve God upon this mountain.

And*p Moses said unto God, Behold, when I come unto the children of Israel, and shall say unto them, The God of your fathers hath sent me unto you; and they shall say to me, What is his name? what shall I say unto them?
And*p God said unto Moses, I AM THAT I AM: and he said, Thus shalt thou say unto the children of Israel, I AM hath sent me unto you.

And*p God said moreover unto Moses, Thus shalt thou say unto the children of Israel, The Lord*s God of your fathers, the God of Abraham, the God of Isaac, and the God of Jacob, hath sent me unto you: this is my name for ever, and this is my memorial unto all generations.

Go,*p and gather the elders of Israel together, and say unto them, The Lord*s God of your fathers, the God of Abraham, of Isaac, and of Jacob, appeared unto me, saying, I have surely visited you, and seen that which is done to you in Egypt:

And*p I have said, I will bring you up out of the affliction of Egypt unto the land of the Canaanites, and the Hittites, and the Amorites, and the Perizzites, and the Hivites, and the Jebusites, unto a land flowing with milk and honey.

And*p they shall hearken to thy voice: and thou shalt come, thou and the elders of Israel, unto the king of Egypt, and ye shall say unto him, The Lord*s God of the Hebrews hath met with us: and now let us go, we beseech thee, three days' journey into the wilderness, that we may sacrifice to the Lord*s our God.
And*p I am sure that the king of Egypt will not let you go, no, not by a mighty hand.
And*p I will stretch out my hand, and smite Egypt with all my wonders which I will do in the midst thereof: and after that he will let you go.
And*p I will give this people favour in the sight of the Egyptians: and it shall come to pass, that, when ye go, ye shall not go empty:

But*p every woman shall borrow of her neighbour, and of her that sojourneth in her house, jewels of silver, and jewels of gold, and raiment: and ye shall put them upon your sons, and upon your daughters; and ye shall spoil the Egyptians.
Exodus 4
And*p Moses answered and said, But, behold, they will not believe me, nor hearken unto my voice: for they will say, The Lord*s hath not appeared unto thee.
And*p the Lord*s said unto him, What is that in thine hand? And he said, A rod.
And*p he said, Cast it on the ground. And he cast it on the ground, and it became a serpent; and Moses fled from before it.
And*p the Lord*s said unto Moses, Put forth thine hand, and take it by the tail. And he put forth his hand, and caught it, and it became a rod in his hand:
That*p they may believe that the Lord*s God of their fathers, the God of Abraham, the God of Isaac, and the God of Jacob, hath appeared unto thee.
And*p the Lord*s said furthermore unto him, Put now thine hand into thy bosom. And he put his hand into his bosom: and when he took it out, behold, his hand was leprous as snow.
And*p he said, Put thine hand into thy bosom again. And he put his hand into his bosom again; and plucked it out of his bosom, and, behold, it was turned again as his other flesh.
And*p it shall come to pass, if they will not believe thee, neither hearken to the voice of the first sign, that they will believe the voice of the latter sign.

And*p it shall come to pass, if they will not believe also these two signs, neither hearken unto thy voice, that thou shalt take of the water of the river, and pour it upon the dry land: and the water which thou takest out of the river shall become blood upon the dry land.
And*p Moses said unto the Lord,*s O my Lord, I am not eloquent, neither heretofore, nor since thou hast spoken unto thy servant: but I am slow of speech, and of a slow tongue.
And*p the Lord*s said unto him, Who hath made man's mouth? or who maketh the dumb, or deaf, or the seeing, or the blind? have not I the Lord?*s
Now*p therefore go, and I will be with thy mouth, and teach thee what thou shalt say.
And*p he said, O my Lord, send, I pray thee, by the hand of him whom thou wilt send.

And*p the anger of the Lord*s was kindled against Moses, and he said, Is not Aaron the Levite thy brother? I know that he can speak well. And also, behold, he cometh forth to meet thee: and when he seeth thee, he will be glad in his heart.
And*p thou shalt speak unto him, and put words in his mouth: and I will be with thy mouth, and with his mouth, and will teach you what ye shall do.
And*p he shall be thy spokesman unto the people: and he shall be, even he shall be to thee instead of a mouth, and thou shalt be to him instead of God.
And*p thou shalt take this rod in thine hand, wherewith thou shalt do signs.

And*p Moses went and returned to Jethro his father in law, and said unto him, Let me go, I pray thee, and return unto my brethren which are in Egypt, and see whether they be yet alive. And Jethro said to Moses, Go in peace.
And*p the Lord*s said unto Moses in Midian, Go, return into Egypt: for all the men are dead which sought thy life.
And*p Moses took his wife and his sons, and set them upon an ass, and he returned to the land of Egypt: and Moses took the rod of God in his hand.

And*p the Lord*s said unto Moses, When thou goest to return into Egypt, see that thou do all those wonders before Pharaoh, which I have put in thine hand: but I will harden his heart, that he shall not let the people go.
And*p thou shalt say unto Pharaoh, Thus saith the Lord,*s Israel is my son, even my firstborn:
And*p I say unto thee, Let my son go, that he may serve me: and if thou refuse to let him go, behold, I will slay thy son, even thy firstborn.
And*p it came to pass by the way in the inn, that the Lord*s met him, and sought to kill him.
Then*p Zipporah took a sharp stone, and cut off the foreskin of her son, and cast it at his feet, and said, Surely a bloody husband art thou to me.
So*p he let him go: then she said, A bloody husband thou art, because of the circumcision.
And*p the Lord*s said to Aaron, Go into the wilderness to meet Moses. And he went, and met him in the mount of God, and kissed him.
And*p Moses told Aaron all the words of the Lord*s who had sent him, and all the signs which he had commanded him.
And*p Moses and Aaron went and gathered together all the elders of the children of Israel:
And*p Aaron spake all the words which the Lord*s had spoken unto Moses, and did the signs in the sight of the people.
And*p the people believed: and when they heard that the Lord*s had visited the children of Israel, and that he had looked upon their affliction, then they bowed their heads and worshipped.
Exodus 5
And*p afterward Moses and Aaron went in, and told Pharaoh, Thus saith the Lord*s God of Israel, Let my people go, that they may hold a feast unto me in the wilderness.
And*p Pharaoh said, Who is the Lord,*s that I should obey his voice to let Israel go? I know not the Lord,*s neither will I let Israel go.

And*p they said, The God of the Hebrews hath met with us: let us go, we pray thee, three days' journey into the desert, and sacrifice unto the Lord*s our God; lest he fall upon us with pestilence, or with the sword.
And*p the king of Egypt said unto them, Wherefore do ye, Moses and Aaron, let the people from their works? get you unto your burdens.
And*p Pharaoh said, Behold, the people of the land now are many, and ye make them rest from their burdens.
And*p Pharaoh commanded the same day the taskmasters of the people, and their officers, saying,
Ye*p shall no more give the people straw to make brick, as heretofore: let them go and gather straw for themselves.

And*p the tale of the bricks, which they did make heretofore, ye shall lay upon them; ye shall not diminish ought thereof: for they be idle; therefore they cry, saying, Let us go and sacrifice to our God.
Let*p there more work be laid upon the men, that they may labour therein; and let them not regard vain words.
And*p the taskmasters of the people went out, and their officers, and they spake to the people, saying, Thus saith Pharaoh, I will not give you straw.
Go*p ye, get you straw where ye can find it: yet not ought of your work shall be diminished.
So*p the people were scattered abroad throughout all the land of Egypt to gather stubble instead of straw.
And*p the taskmasters hasted them, saying, Fulfil your works, your daily tasks, as when there was straw.

And*p the officers of the children of Israel, which Pharaoh's taskmasters had set over them, were beaten, and demanded, Wherefore have ye not fulfilled your task in making brick both yesterday and to day, as heretofore?
Then*p the officers of the children of Israel came and cried unto Pharaoh, saying, Wherefore dealest thou thus with thy servants?
There*p is no straw given unto thy servants, and they say to us, Make brick: and, behold, thy servants are beaten; but the fault is in thine own people.
But*p he said, Ye are idle, ye are idle: therefore ye say, Let us go and do sacrifice to the Lord.*s
Go*p therefore now, and work; for there shall no straw be given you, yet shall ye deliver the tale of bricks.
And*p the officers of the children of Israel did see that they were in evil case, after it was said, Ye shall not minish ought from your bricks of your daily task.
And*p they met Moses and Aaron, who stood in the way, as they came forth from Pharaoh:

And*p they said unto them, The Lord*s look upon you, and judge; because ye have made our savour to be abhorred in the eyes of Pharaoh, and in the eyes of his servants, to put a sword in their hand to slay us.
And*p Moses returned unto the Lord,*s and said, Lord, wherefore hast thou so evil entreated this people? why is it that thou hast sent me?
For*p since I came to Pharaoh to speak in thy name, he hath done evil to this people; neither hast thou delivered thy people at all.
Exodus 6
Then*p the Lord*s said unto Moses, Now shalt thou see what I will do to Pharaoh: for with a strong hand shall he let them go, and with a strong hand shall he drive them out of his land.
And*p God spake unto Moses, and said unto him, I am the Lord:*s
And*p I appeared unto Abraham, unto Isaac, and unto Jacob, by the name of God Almighty, but by my name Jehovah*s was I not known to them.
And*p I have also established my covenant with them, to give them the land of Canaan, the land of their pilgrimage, wherein they were strangers.
And*p I have also heard the groaning of the children of Israel, whom the Egyptians keep in bondage; and I have remembered my covenant.

Wherefore*p say unto the children of Israel, I am the Lord,*s and I will bring you out from under the burdens of the Egyptians, and I will rid you out of their bondage, and I will redeem you with a stretched out arm, and with great judgments:
And*p I will take you to me for a people, and I will be to you a God: and ye shall know that I am the Lord*s your God, which bringeth you out from under the burdens of the Egyptians.
And*p I will bring you in unto the land, concerning the which I did swear to give it to Abraham, to Isaac, and to Jacob; and I will give it you for an heritage: I am the Lord.*s
And*p Moses spake so unto the children of Israel: but they hearkened not unto Moses for anguish of spirit, and for cruel bondage.
And*p the Lord*s spake unto Moses, saying,
Go*p in, speak unto Pharaoh king of Egypt, that he let the children of Israel go out of his land.
And*p Moses spake before the Lord,*s saying, Behold, the children of Israel have not hearkened unto me; how then shall Pharaoh hear me, who am of uncircumcised lips?
And*p the Lord*s spake unto Moses and unto Aaron, and gave them a charge unto the children of Israel, and unto Pharaoh king of Egypt, to bring the children of Israel out of the land of Egypt.
These*p be the heads of their fathers' houses: The sons of Reuben the firstborn of Israel; Hanoch, and Pallu, Hezron, and Carmi: these be the families of Reuben.
And*p the sons of Simeon; Jemuel, and Jamin, and Ohad, and Jachin, and Zohar, and Shaul the son of a Canaanitish woman: these are the families of Simeon.
And*p these are the names of the sons of Levi according to their generations; Gershon, and Kohath, and Merari: and the years of the life of Levi were an hundred thirty and seven years.
The*p sons of Gershon; Libni, and Shimei, according to their families.
And*p the sons of Kohath; Amram, and Izhar, and Hebron, and Uzziel: and the years of the life of Kohath were an hundred thirty and three years.
And*p the sons of Merari; Mahli and Mushi: these are the families of Levi according to their generations.
And*p Amram took him Jochebed his father's sister to wife; and she bare him Aaron and Moses: and the years of the life of Amram were an hundred and thirty and seven years.
And*p the sons of Izhar; Korah, and Nepheg, and Zichri.
And*p the sons of Uzziel; Mishael, and Elzaphan, and Zithri.
And*p Aaron took him Elisheba, daughter of Amminadab, sister of Nahshon, to wife; and she bare him Nadab, and Abihu, Eleazar, and Ithamar.
And*p the sons of Korah; Assir, and Elkanah, and Abiasaph: these are the families of the Korhites.
And*p Eleazar Aaron's son took him one of the daughters of Putiel to wife; and she bare him Phinehas: these are the heads of the fathers of the Levites according to their families.
These*p are that Aaron and Moses, to whom the Lord*s said, Bring out the children of Israel from the land of Egypt according to their armies.
These*p are they which spake to Pharaoh king of Egypt, to bring out the children of Israel from Egypt: these are that Moses and Aaron.
And*p it came to pass on the day when the Lord*s spake unto Moses in the land of Egypt,
That*p the Lord*s spake unto Moses, saying, I am the Lord:*s speak thou unto Pharaoh king of Egypt all that I say unto thee.
And*p Moses said before the Lord,*s Behold, I am of uncircumcised lips, and how shall Pharaoh hearken unto me?
Exodus 7
And*p the Lord*s said unto Moses, See, I have made thee a god to Pharaoh: and Aaron thy brother shall be thy prophet.
Thou*p shalt speak all that I command thee: and Aaron thy brother shall speak unto Pharaoh, that he send the children of Israel out of his land.
And*p I will harden Pharaoh's heart, and multiply my signs and my wonders in the land of Egypt.
But*p Pharaoh shall not hearken unto you, that I may lay my hand upon Egypt, and bring forth mine armies, and my people the children of Israel, out of the land of Egypt by great judgments.
And*p the Egyptians shall know that I am the Lord,*s when I stretch forth mine hand upon Egypt, and bring out the children of Israel from among them.
And*p Moses and Aaron did as the Lord*s commanded them, so did they.
And*p Moses was fourscore years old, and Aaron fourscore and three years old, when they spake unto Pharaoh.
And*p the Lord*s spake unto Moses and unto Aaron, saying,
When*p Pharaoh shall speak unto you, saying, Shew a miracle for you: then thou shalt say unto Aaron, Take thy rod, and cast it before Pharaoh, and it shall become a serpent.
And*p Moses and Aaron went in unto Pharaoh, and they did so as the Lord*s had commanded: and Aaron cast down his rod before Pharaoh, and before his servants, and it became a serpent.
Then*p Pharaoh also called the wise men and the sorcerers: now the magicians of Egypt, they also did in like manner with their enchantments.
For*p they cast down every man his rod, and they became serpents: but Aaron's rod swallowed up their rods.
And*p he hardened Pharaoh's heart, that he hearkened not unto them; as the Lord*s had said.
And*p the Lord*s said unto Moses, Pharaoh's heart is hardened, he refuseth to let the people go.

Get*p thee unto Pharaoh in the morning; lo, he goeth out unto the water; and thou shalt stand by the river's brink against he come; and the rod which was turned to a serpent shalt thou take in thine hand.
And*p thou shalt say unto him, The Lord*s God of the Hebrews hath sent me unto thee, saying, Let my people go, that they may serve me in the wilderness: and, behold, hitherto thou wouldest not hear.

Thus*p saith the Lord,*s In this thou shalt know that I am the Lord:*s behold, I will smite with the rod that is in mine hand upon the waters which are in the river, and they shall be turned to blood.
And*p the fish that is in the river shall die, and the river shall stink; and the Egyptians shall lothe to drink of the water of the river.

And*p the Lord*s spake unto Moses, Say unto Aaron, Take thy rod, and stretch out thine hand upon the waters of Egypt, upon their streams, upon their rivers, and upon their ponds, and upon all their pools of water, that they may become blood; and that there may be blood throughout all the land of Egypt, both in vessels of wood, and in vessels of stone.

And*p Moses and Aaron did so, as the Lord*s commanded; and he lifted up the rod, and smote the waters that were in the river, in the sight of Pharaoh, and in the sight of his servants; and all the waters that were in the river were turned to blood.
And*p the fish that was in the river died; and the river stank, and the Egyptians could not drink of the water of the river; and there was blood throughout all the land of Egypt.
And*p the magicians of Egypt did so with their enchantments: and Pharaoh's heart was hardened, neither did he hearken unto them; as the Lord*s had said.
And*p Pharaoh turned and went into his house, neither did he set his heart to this also.
And*p all the Egyptians digged round about the river for water to drink; for they could not drink of the water of the river.
And*p seven days were fulfilled, after that the Lord*s had smitten the river.
Exodus 8
And*p the Lord*s spake unto Moses, Go unto Pharaoh, and say unto him, Thus saith the Lord,*s Let my people go, that they may serve me.
And*p if thou refuse to let them go, behold, I will smite all thy borders with frogs:

And*p the river shall bring forth frogs abundantly, which shall go up and come into thine house, and into thy bedchamber, and upon thy bed, and into the house of thy servants, and upon thy people, and into thine ovens, and into thy kneadingtroughs:
And*p the frogs shall come up both on thee, and upon thy people, and upon all thy servants.
And*p the Lord*s spake unto Moses, Say unto Aaron, Stretch forth thine hand with thy rod over the streams, over the rivers, and over the ponds, and cause frogs to come up upon the land of Egypt.
And*p Aaron stretched out his hand over the waters of Egypt; and the frogs came up, and covered the land of Egypt.
And*p the magicians did so with their enchantments, and brought up frogs upon the land of Egypt.

Then*p Pharaoh called for Moses and Aaron, and said, Entreat the Lord,*s that he may take away the frogs from me, and from my people; and I will let the people go, that they may do sacrifice unto the Lord.*s

And*p Moses said unto Pharaoh, Glory over me: when shall I entreat for thee, and for thy servants, and for thy people, to destroy the frogs from thee and thy houses, that they may remain in the river only?
And*p he said, To morrow. And he said, Be it according to thy word: that thou mayest know that there is none like unto the Lord*s our God.
And*p the frogs shall depart from thee, and from thy houses, and from thy servants, and from thy people; they shall remain in the river only.
And*p Moses and Aaron went out from Pharaoh: and Moses cried unto the Lord*s because of the frogs which he had brought against Pharaoh.
And*p the Lord*s did according to the word of Moses; and the frogs died out of the houses, out of the villages, and out of the fields.
And*p they gathered them together upon heaps: and the land stank.
But*p when Pharaoh saw that there was respite, he hardened his heart, and hearkened not unto them; as the Lord*s had said.
And*p the Lord*s said unto Moses, Say unto Aaron, Stretch out thy rod, and smite the dust of the land, that it may become lice throughout all the land of Egypt.

And*p they did so; for Aaron stretched out his hand with his rod, and smote the dust of the earth, and it became lice in man, and in beast; all the dust of the land became lice throughout all the land of Egypt.
And*p the magicians did so with their enchantments to bring forth lice, but they could not: so there were lice upon man, and upon beast.
Then*p the magicians said unto Pharaoh, This is the finger of God: and Pharaoh's heart was hardened, and he hearkened not unto them; as the Lord*s had said.

And*p the Lord*s said unto Moses, Rise up early in the morning, and stand before Pharaoh; lo, he cometh forth to the water; and say unto him, Thus saith the Lord,*s Let my people go, that they may serve me.

Else,*p if thou wilt not let my people go, behold, I will send swarms of flies upon thee, and upon thy servants, and upon thy people, and into thy houses: and the houses of the Egyptians shall be full of swarms of flies, and also the ground whereon they are.
And*p I will sever in that day the land of Goshen, in which my people dwell, that no swarms of flies shall be there; to the end thou mayest know that I am the Lord*s in the midst of the earth.
And*p I will put a division between my people and thy people: to morrow shall this sign be.

And*p the Lord*s did so; and there came a grievous swarm of flies into the house of Pharaoh, and into his servants' houses, and into all the land of Egypt: the land was corrupted by reason of the swarm of flies.
And*p Pharaoh called for Moses and for Aaron, and said, Go ye, sacrifice to your God in the land.

And*p Moses said, It is not meet so to do; for we shall sacrifice the abomination of the Egyptians to the Lord*s our God: lo, shall we sacrifice the abomination of the Egyptians before their eyes, and will they not stone us?
We*p will go three days' journey into the wilderness, and sacrifice to the Lord*s our God, as he shall command us.
And*p Pharaoh said, I will let you go, that ye may sacrifice to the Lord*s your God in the wilderness; only ye shall not go very far away: entreat for me.

And*p Moses said, Behold, I go out from thee, and I will entreat the Lord*s that the swarms of flies may depart from Pharaoh, from his servants, and from his people, to morrow: but let not Pharaoh deal deceitfully any more in not letting the people go to sacrifice to the Lord.*s
And*p Moses went out from Pharaoh, and entreated the Lord.*s
And*p the Lord*s did according to the word of Moses; and he removed the swarms of flies from Pharaoh, from his servants, and from his people; there remained not one.
And*p Pharaoh hardened his heart at this time also, neither would he let the people go.
Exodus 9
Then*p the Lord*s said unto Moses, Go in unto Pharaoh, and tell him, Thus saith the Lord*s God of the Hebrews, Let my people go, that they may serve me.
For*p if thou refuse to let them go, and wilt hold them still,
Behold,*p the hand of the Lord*s is upon thy cattle which is in the field, upon the horses, upon the asses, upon the camels, upon the oxen, and upon the sheep: there shall be a very grievous murrain.
And*p the Lord*s shall sever between the cattle of Israel and the cattle of Egypt: and there shall nothing die of all that is the children's of Israel.
And*p the Lord*s appointed a set time, saying, To morrow the Lord*s shall do this thing in the land.
And*p the Lord*s did that thing on the morrow, and all the cattle of Egypt died: but of the cattle of the children of Israel died not one.
And*p Pharaoh sent, and, behold, there was not one of the cattle of the Israelites dead. And the heart of Pharaoh was hardened, and he did not let the people go.
And*p the Lord*s said unto Moses and unto Aaron, Take to you handfuls of ashes of the furnace, and let Moses sprinkle it toward the heaven in the sight of Pharaoh.
And*p it shall become small dust in all the land of Egypt, and shall be a boil breaking forth with blains upon man, and upon beast, throughout all the land of Egypt.
And*p they took ashes of the furnace, and stood before Pharaoh; and Moses sprinkled it up toward heaven; and it became a boil breaking forth with blains upon man, and upon beast.
And*p the magicians could not stand before Moses because of the boils; for the boil was upon the magicians, and upon all the Egyptians.
And*p the Lord*s hardened the heart of Pharaoh, and he hearkened not unto them; as the Lord*s had spoken unto Moses.
And*p the Lord*s said unto Moses, Rise up early in the morning, and stand before Pharaoh, and say unto him, Thus saith the Lord*s God of the Hebrews, Let my people go, that they may serve me.
For*p I will at this time send all my plagues upon thine heart, and upon thy servants, and upon thy people; that thou mayest know that there is none like me in all the earth.
For*p now I will stretch out my hand, that I may smite thee and thy people with pestilence; and thou shalt be cut off from the earth.
And*p in very deed for this cause have I raised thee up, for to shew in thee my power; and that my name may be declared throughout all the earth.
As*p yet exaltest thou thyself against my people, that thou wilt not let them go?
Behold,*p to morrow about this time I will cause it to rain a very grievous hail, such as hath not been in Egypt since the foundation thereof even until now.

Send*p therefore now, and gather thy cattle, and all that thou hast in the field; for upon every man and beast which shall be found in the field, and shall not be brought home, the hail shall come down upon them, and they shall die.
He*p that feared the word of the Lord*s among the servants of Pharaoh made his servants and his cattle flee into the houses:
And*p he that regarded not the word of the Lord*s left his servants and his cattle in the field.

And*p the Lord*s said unto Moses, Stretch forth thine hand toward heaven, that there may be hail in all the land of Egypt, upon man, and upon beast, and upon every herb of the field, throughout the land of Egypt.
And*p Moses stretched forth his rod toward heaven: and the Lord*s sent thunder and hail, and the fire ran along upon the ground; and the Lord*s rained hail upon the land of Egypt.
So*p there was hail, and fire mingled with the hail, very grievous, such as there was none like it in all the land of Egypt since it became a nation.
And*p the hail smote throughout all the land of Egypt all that was in the field, both man and beast; and the hail smote every herb of the field, and brake every tree of the field.
Only*p in the land of Goshen, where the children of Israel were, was there no hail.
And*p Pharaoh sent, and called for Moses and Aaron, and said unto them, I have sinned this time: the Lord*s is righteous, and I and my people are wicked.
Entreat*p the Lord*s (for it is enough) that there be no more mighty thunderings and hail; and I will let you go, and ye shall stay no longer.

And*p Moses said unto him, As soon as I am gone out of the city, I will spread abroad my hands unto the Lord;*s and the thunder shall cease, neither shall there be any more hail; that thou mayest know how that the earth is the Lord's.*s
But*p as for thee and thy servants, I know that ye will not yet fear the Lord*s God.
And*p the flax and the barley was smitten: for the barley was in the ear, and the flax was bolled.
But*p the wheat and the rie were not smitten: for they were not grown up.
And*p Moses went out of the city from Pharaoh, and spread abroad his hands unto the Lord:*s and the thunders and hail ceased, and the rain was not poured upon the earth.
And*p when Pharaoh saw that the rain and the hail and the thunders were ceased, he sinned yet more, and hardened his heart, he and his servants.
And*p the heart of Pharaoh was hardened, neither would he let the children of Israel go; as the Lord*s had spoken by Moses.
Exodus 10
And*p the Lord*s said unto Moses, Go in unto Pharaoh: for I have hardened his heart, and the heart of his servants, that I might shew these my signs before him:
And*p that thou mayest tell in the ears of thy son, and of thy son's son, what things I have wrought in Egypt, and my signs which I have done among them; that ye may know how that I am the Lord.*s

And*p Moses and Aaron came in unto Pharaoh, and said unto him, Thus saith the Lord*s God of the Hebrews, How long wilt thou refuse to humble thyself before me? let my people go, that they may serve me.
Else,*p if thou refuse to let my people go, behold, to morrow will I bring the locusts into thy coast:

And*p they shall cover the face of the earth, that one cannot be able to see the earth: and they shall eat the residue of that which is escaped, which remaineth unto you from the hail, and shall eat every tree which groweth for you out of the field:

And*p they shall fill thy houses, and the houses of all thy servants, and the houses of all the Egyptians; which neither thy fathers, nor thy fathers' fathers have seen, since the day that they were upon the earth unto this day. And he turned himself, and went out from Pharaoh.
And*p Pharaoh's servants said unto him, How long shall this man be a snare unto us? let the men go, that they may serve the Lord*s their God: knowest thou not yet that Egypt is destroyed?
And*p Moses and Aaron were brought again unto Pharaoh: and he said unto them, Go, serve the Lord*s your God: but who are they that shall go?
And*p Moses said, We will go with our young and with our old, with our sons and with our daughters, with our flocks and with our herds will we go; for we must hold a feast unto the Lord.*s
And*p he said unto them, Let the Lord*s be so with you, as I will let you go, and your little ones: look to it; for evil is before you.
Not*p so: go now ye that are men, and serve the Lord;*s for that ye did desire. And they were driven out from Pharaoh's presence.

And*p the Lord*s said unto Moses, Stretch out thine hand over the land of Egypt for the locusts, that they may come up upon the land of Egypt, and eat every herb of the land, even all that the hail hath left.

And*p Moses stretched forth his rod over the land of Egypt, and the Lord*s brought an east wind upon the land all that day, and all that night; and when it was morning, the east wind brought the locusts.
And*p the locusts went up over all the land of Egypt, and rested in all the coasts of Egypt: very grievous were they; before them there were no such locusts as they, neither after them shall be such.

For*p they covered the face of the whole earth, so that the land was darkened; and they did eat every herb of the land, and all the fruit of the trees which the hail had left: and there remained not any green thing in the trees, or in the herbs of the field, through all the land of Egypt.
Then*p Pharaoh called for Moses and Aaron in haste; and he said, I have sinned against the Lord*s your God, and against you.
Now*p therefore forgive, I pray thee, my sin only this once, and entreat the Lord*s your God, that he may take away from me this death only.
And*p he went out from Pharaoh, and entreated the Lord.*s
And*p the Lord*s turned a mighty strong west wind, which took away the locusts, and cast them into the Red sea; there remained not one locust in all the coasts of Egypt.
But*p the Lord*s hardened Pharaoh's heart, so that he would not let the children of Israel go.
And*p the Lord*s said unto Moses, Stretch out thine hand toward heaven, that there may be darkness over the land of Egypt, even darkness which may be felt.
And*p Moses stretched forth his hand toward heaven; and there was a thick darkness in all the land of Egypt three days:
They*p saw not one another, neither rose any from his place for three days: but all the children of Israel had light in their dwellings.
And*p Pharaoh called unto Moses, and said, Go ye, serve the Lord;*s only let your flocks and your herds be stayed: let your little ones also go with you.
And*p Moses said, Thou must give us also sacrifices and burnt offerings, that we may sacrifice unto the Lord*s our God.

Our*p cattle also shall go with us; there shall not an hoof be left behind; for thereof must we take to serve the Lord*s our God; and we know not with what we must serve the Lord,*s until we come thither.
But*p the Lord*s hardened Pharaoh's heart, and he would not let them go.
And*p Pharaoh said unto him, Get thee from me, take heed to thyself, see my face no more; for in that day thou seest my face thou shalt die.
And*p Moses said, Thou hast spoken well, I will see thy face again no more.
Exodus 11

And*p the Lord*s said unto Moses, Yet will I bring one plague more upon Pharaoh, and upon Egypt; afterwards he will let you go hence: when he shall let you go, he shall surely thrust you out hence altogether.
Speak*p now in the ears of the people, and let every man borrow of his neighbour, and every woman of her neighbour, jewels of silver, and jewels of gold.
And*p the Lord*s gave the people favour in the sight of the Egyptians. Moreover the man Moses was very great in the land of Egypt, in the sight of Pharaoh's servants, and in the sight of the people.
And*p Moses said, Thus saith the Lord,*s About midnight will I go out into the midst of Egypt:

And*p all the firstborn in the land of Egypt shall die, from the firstborn of Pharaoh that sitteth upon his throne, even unto the firstborn of the maidservant that is behind the mill; and all the firstborn of beasts.
And*p there shall be a great cry throughout all the land of Egypt, such as there was none like it, nor shall be like it any more.
But*p against any of the children of Israel shall not a dog move his tongue, against man or beast: that ye may know how that the Lord*s doth put a difference between the Egyptians and Israel.

And*p all these thy servants shall come down unto me, and bow down themselves unto me, saying, Get thee out, and all the people that follow thee: and after that I will go out. And he went out from Pharaoh in a great anger.
And*p the Lord*s said unto Moses, Pharaoh shall not hearken unto you; that my wonders may be multiplied in the land of Egypt.
And*p Moses and Aaron did all these wonders before Pharaoh: and the Lord*s hardened Pharaoh's heart, so that he would not let the children of Israel go out of his land.
Exodus 12
And*p the Lord*s spake unto Moses and Aaron in the land of Egypt, saying,
This*p month shall be unto you the beginning of months: it shall be the first month of the year to you.
Speak*p ye unto all the congregation of Israel, saying, In the tenth day of this month they shall take to them every man a lamb, according to the house of their fathers, a lamb for an house:

And*p if the household be too little for the lamb, let him and his neighbour next unto his house take it according to the number of the souls; every man according to his eating shall make your count for the lamb.
Your*p lamb shall be without blemish, a male of the first year: ye shall take it out from the sheep, or from the goats:
And*p ye shall keep it up until the fourteenth day of the same month: and the whole assembly of the congregation of Israel shall kill it in the evening.
And*p they shall take of the blood, and strike it on the two side posts and on the upper door post of the houses, wherein they shall eat it.
And*p they shall eat the flesh in that night, roast with fire, and unleavened bread; and with bitter herbs they shall eat it.
Eat*p not of it raw, nor sodden at all with water, but roast with fire; his head with his legs, and with the purtenance thereof.
And*p ye shall let nothing of it remain until the morning; and that which remaineth of it until the morning ye shall burn with fire.
And*p thus shall ye eat it; with your loins girded, your shoes on your feet, and your staff in your hand; and ye shall eat it in haste: it is the Lord's*s passover.

For*p I will pass through the land of Egypt this night, and will smite all the firstborn in the land of Egypt, both man and beast; and against all the gods of Egypt I will execute judgment: I am the Lord.*s

And*p the blood shall be to you for a token upon the houses where ye are: and when I see the blood, I will pass over you, and the plague shall not be upon you to destroy you, when I smite the land of Egypt.
And*p this day shall be unto you for a memorial; and ye shall keep it a feast to the Lord*s throughout your generations; ye shall keep it a feast by an ordinance for ever.

Seven*p days shall ye eat unleavened bread; even the first day ye shall put away leaven out of your houses: for whosoever eateth leavened bread from the first day until the seventh day, that soul shall be cut off from Israel.

And*p in the first day there shall be an holy convocation, and in the seventh day there shall be an holy convocation to you; no manner of work shall be done in them, save that which every man must eat, that only may be done of you.

And*p ye shall observe the feast of unleavened bread; for in this selfsame day have I brought your armies out of the land of Egypt: therefore shall ye observe this day in your generations by an ordinance for ever.
In*p the first month, on the fourteenth day of the month at even, ye shall eat unleavened bread, until the one and twentieth day of the month at even.

Seven*p days shall there be no leaven found in your houses: for whosoever eateth that which is leavened, even that soul shall be cut off from the congregation of Israel, whether he be a stranger, or born in the land.
Ye*p shall eat nothing leavened; in all your habitations shall ye eat unleavened bread.
Then*p Moses called for all the elders of Israel, and said unto them, Draw out and take you a lamb according to your families, and kill the passover.

And*p ye shall take a bunch of hyssop, and dip it in the blood that is in the basin, and strike the lintel and the two side posts with the blood that is in the basin; and none of you shall go out at the door of his house until the morning.

For*p the Lord*s will pass through to smite the Egyptians; and when he seeth the blood upon the lintel, and on the two side posts, the Lord*s will pass over the door, and will not suffer the destroyer to come in unto your houses to smite you.
And*p ye shall observe this thing for an ordinance to thee and to thy sons for ever.
And*p it shall come to pass, when ye be come to the land which the Lord*s will give you, according as he hath promised, that ye shall keep this service.
And*p it shall come to pass, when your children shall say unto you, What mean ye by this service?

That*p ye shall say, It is the sacrifice of the Lord's*s passover, who passed over the houses of the children of Israel in Egypt, when he smote the Egyptians, and delivered our houses. And the people bowed the head and worshipped.
And*p the children of Israel went away, and did as the Lord*s had commanded Moses and Aaron, so did they.

And*p it came to pass, that at midnight the Lord*s smote all the firstborn in the land of Egypt, from the firstborn of Pharaoh that sat on his throne unto the firstborn of the captive that was in the dungeon; and all the firstborn of cattle.
And*p Pharaoh rose up in the night, he, and all his servants, and all the Egyptians; and there was a great cry in Egypt; for there was not a house where there was not one dead.
And*p he called for Moses and Aaron by night, and said, Rise up, and get you forth from among my people, both ye and the children of Israel; and go, serve the Lord,*s as ye have said.
Also*p take your flocks and your herds, as ye have said, and be gone; and bless me also.
And*p the Egyptians were urgent upon the people, that they might send them out of the land in haste; for they said, We be all dead men.
And*p the people took their dough before it was leavened, their kneadingtroughs being bound up in their clothes upon their shoulders.
And*p the children of Israel did according to the word of Moses; and they borrowed of the Egyptians jewels of silver, and jewels of gold, and raiment:
And*p the Lord*s gave the people favour in the sight of the Egyptians, so that they lent unto them such things as they required. And they spoiled the Egyptians.
And*p the children of Israel journeyed from Rameses to Succoth, about six hundred thousand on foot that were men, beside children.
And*p a mixed multitude went up also with them; and flocks, and herds, even very much cattle.

And*p they baked unleavened cakes of the dough which they brought forth out of Egypt, for it was not leavened; because they were thrust out of Egypt, and could not tarry, neither had they prepared for themselves any victual.
Now*p the sojourning of the children of Israel, who dwelt in Egypt, was four hundred and thirty years.
And*p it came to pass at the end of the four hundred and thirty years, even the selfsame day it came to pass, that all the hosts of the Lord*s went out from the land of Egypt.
It*p is a night to be much observed unto the Lord*s for bringing them out from the land of Egypt: this is that night of the Lord*s to be observed of all the children of Israel in their generations.
And*p the Lord*s said unto Moses and Aaron, This is the ordinance of the passover: There shall no stranger eat thereof:
But*p every man's servant that is bought for money, when thou hast circumcised him, then shall he eat thereof.
A*p foreigner and an hired servant shall not eat thereof.
In*p one house shall it be eaten; thou shalt not carry forth ought of the flesh abroad out of the house; neither shall ye break a bone thereof.
All*p the congregation of Israel shall keep it.

And*p when a stranger shall sojourn with thee, and will keep the passover to the Lord,*s let all his males be circumcised, and then let him come near and keep it; and he shall be as one that is born in the land: for no uncircumcised person shall eat thereof.
One*p law shall be to him that is homeborn, and unto the stranger that sojourneth among you.
Thus*p did all the children of Israel; as the Lord*s commanded Moses and Aaron, so did they.
And*p it came to pass the selfsame day, that the Lord*s did bring the children of Israel out of the land of Egypt by their armies.
Exodus 13
And*p the Lord*s spake unto Moses, saying,
Sanctify*p unto me all the firstborn, whatsoever openeth the womb among the children of Israel, both of man and of beast: it is mine.

And*p Moses said unto the people, Remember this day, in which ye came out from Egypt, out of the house of bondage; for by strength of hand the Lord*s brought you out from this place: there shall no leavened bread be eaten.
This*p day came ye out in the month Abib.

And*p it shall be when the Lord*s shall bring thee into the land of the Canaanites, and the Hittites, and the Amorites, and the Hivites, and the Jebusites, which he sware unto thy fathers to give thee, a land flowing with milk and honey, that thou shalt keep this service in this month.
Seven*p days thou shalt eat unleavened bread, and in the seventh day shall be a feast to the Lord.*s
Unleavened*p bread shall be eaten seven days; and there shall no leavened bread be seen with thee, neither shall there be leaven seen with thee in all thy quarters.
And*p thou shalt shew thy son in that day, saying, This is done because of that which the Lord*s did unto me when I came forth out of Egypt.

And*p it shall be for a sign unto thee upon thine hand, and for a memorial between thine eyes, that the Lord's*s law may be in thy mouth: for with a strong hand hath the Lord*s brought thee out of Egypt.
Thou*p shalt therefore keep this ordinance in his season from year to year.
And*p it shall be when the Lord*s shall bring thee into the land of the Canaanites, as he sware unto thee and to thy fathers, and shall give it thee,
That*p thou shalt set apart unto the Lord*s all that openeth the matrix, and every firstling that cometh of a beast which thou hast; the males shall be the Lord's.*s
And*p every firstling of an ass thou shalt redeem with a lamb; and if thou wilt not redeem it, then thou shalt break his neck: and all the firstborn of man among thy children shalt thou redeem.
And*p it shall be when thy son asketh thee in time to come, saying, What is this? that thou shalt say unto him, By strength of hand the Lord*s brought us out from Egypt, from the house of bondage:

And*p it came to pass, when Pharaoh would hardly let us go, that the Lord*s slew all the firstborn in the land of Egypt, both the firstborn of man, and the firstborn of beast: therefore I sacrifice to the Lord*s all that openeth the matrix, being males; but all the firstborn of my children I redeem.
And*p it shall be for a token upon thine hand, and for frontlets between thine eyes: for by strength of hand the Lord*s brought us forth out of Egypt.

And*p it came to pass, when Pharaoh had let the people go, that God led them not through the way of the land of the Philistines, although that was near; for God said, Lest peradventure the people repent when they see war, and they return to Egypt:
But*p God led the people about, through the way of the wilderness of the Red sea: and the children of Israel went up harnessed out of the land of Egypt.
And*p Moses took the bones of Joseph with him: for he had straitly sworn the children of Israel, saying, God will surely visit you; and ye shall carry up my bones away hence with you.
And*p they took their journey from Succoth, and encamped in Etham, in the edge of the wilderness.
And*p the Lord*s went before them by day in a pillar of a cloud, to lead them the way; and by night in a pillar of fire, to give them light; to go by day and night:
He*p took not away the pillar of the cloud by day, nor the pillar of fire by night, from before the people.
Exodus 14
And*p the Lord*s spake unto Moses, saying,
Speak*p unto the children of Israel, that they turn and encamp before Pi–hahiroth, between Migdol and the sea, over against Baal–zephon: before it shall ye encamp by the sea.
For*p Pharaoh will say of the children of Israel, They are entangled in the land, the wilderness hath shut them in.
And*p I will harden Pharaoh's heart, that he shall follow after them; and I will be honoured upon Pharaoh, and upon all his host; that the Egyptians may know that I am the Lord.*s And they did so.

And*p it was told the king of Egypt that the people fled: and the heart of Pharaoh and of his servants was turned against the people, and they said, Why have we done this, that we have let Israel go from serving us?
And*p he made ready his chariot, and took his people with him:
And*p he took six hundred chosen chariots, and all the chariots of Egypt, and captains over every one of them.
And*p the Lord*s hardened the heart of Pharaoh king of Egypt, and he pursued after the children of Israel: and the children of Israel went out with an high hand.
But*p the Egyptians pursued after them, all the horses and chariots of Pharaoh, and his horsemen, and his army, and overtook them encamping by the sea, beside Pi–hahiroth, before Baal–zephon.

And*p when Pharaoh drew nigh, the children of Israel lifted up their eyes, and, behold, the Egyptians marched after them; and they were sore afraid: and the children of Israel cried out unto the Lord.*s
And*p they said unto Moses, Because there were no graves in Egypt, hast thou taken us away to die in the wilderness? wherefore hast thou dealt thus with us, to carry us forth out of Egypt?

Is*p not this the word that we did tell thee in Egypt, saying, Let us alone, that we may serve the Egyptians? For it had been better for us to serve the Egyptians, than that we should die in the wilderness.

And*p Moses said unto the people, Fear ye not, stand still, and see the salvation of the Lord,*s which he will shew to you to day: for the Egyptians whom ye have seen to day, ye shall see them again no more for ever.
The*p Lord*s shall fight for you, and ye shall hold your peace.
And*p the Lord*s said unto Moses, Wherefore criest thou unto me? speak unto the children of Israel, that they go forward:
But*p lift thou up thy rod, and stretch out thine hand over the sea, and divide it: and the children of Israel shall go on dry ground through the midst of the sea.
And*p I, behold, I will harden the hearts of the Egyptians, and they shall follow them: and I will get me honour upon Pharaoh, and upon all his host, upon his chariots, and upon his horsemen.
And*p the Egyptians shall know that I am the Lord,*s when I have gotten me honour upon Pharaoh, upon his chariots, and upon his horsemen.
And*p the angel of God, which went before the camp of Israel, removed and went behind them; and the pillar of the cloud went from before their face, and stood behind them:

And*p it came between the camp of the Egyptians and the camp of Israel; and it was a cloud and darkness to them, but it gave light by night to these: so that the one came not near the other all the night.
And*p Moses stretched out his hand over the sea; and the Lord*s caused the sea to go back by a strong east wind all that night, and made the sea dry land, and the waters were divided.
And*p the children of Israel went into the midst of the sea upon the dry ground: and the waters were a wall unto them on their right hand, and on their left.
And*p the Egyptians pursued, and went in after them to the midst of the sea, even all Pharaoh's horses, his chariots, and his horsemen.
And*p it came to pass, that in the morning watch the Lord*s looked unto the host of the Egyptians through the pillar of fire and of the cloud, and troubled the host of the Egyptians,
And*p took off their chariot wheels, that they drave them heavily: so that the Egyptians said, Let us flee from the face of Israel; for the Lord*s fighteth for them against the Egyptians.
And*p the Lord*s said unto Moses, Stretch out thine hand over the sea, that the waters may come again upon the Egyptians, upon their chariots, and upon their horsemen.

And*p Moses stretched forth his hand over the sea, and the sea returned to his strength when the morning appeared; and the Egyptians fled against it; and the Lord*s overthrew the Egyptians in the midst of the sea.
And*p the waters returned, and covered the chariots, and the horsemen, and all the host of Pharaoh that came into the sea after them; there remained not so much as one of them.
But*p the children of Israel walked upon dry land in the midst of the sea; and the waters were a wall unto them on their right hand, and on their left.
Thus*p the Lord*s saved Israel that day out of the hand of the Egyptians; and Israel saw the Egyptians dead upon the sea shore.
And*p Israel saw that great work which the Lord*s did upon the Egyptians: and the people feared the Lord,*s and believed the Lord,*s and his servant Moses.
Exodus 15

Then*p sang Moses and the children of Israel this song unto the Lord,*s and spake, saying, I will sing unto the Lord,*s for he hath triumphed gloriously: the horse and his rider hath he thrown into the sea.
The*p Lord*s is my strength and song, and he is become my salvation: he is my God, and I will prepare him an habitation; my father's God, and I will exalt him.
The*p Lord*s is a man of war: the Lord*s is his name.
Pharaoh's*p chariots and his host hath he cast into the sea: his chosen captains also are drowned in the Red sea.
The*p depths have covered them: they sank into the bottom as a stone.
Thy*p right hand, O Lord,*s is become glorious in power: thy right hand, O Lord,*s hath dashed in pieces the enemy.
And*p in the greatness of thine excellency thou hast overthrown them that rose up against thee: thou sentest forth thy wrath, which consumed them as stubble.
And*p with the blast of thy nostrils the waters were gathered together, the floods stood upright as an heap, and the depths were congealed in the heart of the sea.
The*p enemy said, I will pursue, I will overtake, I will divide the spoil; my lust shall be satisfied upon them; I will draw my sword, my hand shall destroy them.
Thou*p didst blow with thy wind, the sea covered them: they sank as lead in the mighty waters.
Who*p is like unto thee, O Lord,*s among the gods? who is like thee, glorious in holiness, fearful in praises, doing wonders?
Thou*p stretchedst out thy right hand, the earth swallowed them.
Thou*p in thy mercy hast led forth the people which thou hast redeemed: thou hast guided them in thy strength unto thy holy habitation.
The*p people shall hear, and be afraid: sorrow shall take hold on the inhabitants of Philistia.
Then*p the dukes of Edom shall be amazed; the mighty men of Moab, trembling shall take hold upon them; all the inhabitants of Canaan shall melt away.
Fear*p and dread shall fall upon them; by the greatness of thine arm they shall be as still as a stone; till thy people pass over, O Lord,*s till the people pass over, which thou hast purchased.

Thou*p shalt bring them in, and plant them in the mountain of thine inheritance, in the place, O Lord,*s which thou hast made for thee to dwell in, in the Sanctuary, O Lord, which thy hands have established.
The*p Lord*s shall reign for ever and ever.

For*p the horse of Pharaoh went in with his chariots and with his horsemen into the sea, and the Lord*s brought again the waters of the sea upon them; but the children of Israel went on dry land in the midst of the sea.
And*p Miriam the prophetess, the sister of Aaron, took a timbrel in her hand; and all the women went out after her with timbrels and with dances.
And*p Miriam answered them, Sing ye to the Lord,*s for he hath triumphed gloriously; the horse and his rider hath he thrown into the sea.
So*p Moses brought Israel from the Red sea, and they went out into the wilderness of Shur; and they went three days in the wilderness, and found no water.
And*p when they came to Marah, they could not drink of the waters of Marah, for they were bitter: therefore the name of it was called Marah.
And*p the people murmured against Moses, saying, What shall we drink?

And*p he cried unto the Lord;*s and the Lord*s shewed him a tree, which when he had cast into the waters, the waters were made sweet: there he made for them a statute and an ordinance, and there he proved them,

And*p said, If thou wilt diligently hearken to the voice of the Lord*s thy God, and wilt do that which is right in his sight, and wilt give ear to his commandments, and keep all his statutes, I will put none of these diseases upon thee, which I have brought upon the Egyptians: for I am the Lord*s that healeth thee.
And*p they came to Elim, where were twelve wells of water, and threescore and ten palm trees: and they encamped there by the waters.
Exodus 16

And*p they took their journey from Elim, and all the congregation of the children of Israel came unto the wilderness of Sin, which is between Elim and Sinai, on the fifteenth day of the second month after their departing out of the land of Egypt.
And*p the whole congregation of the children of Israel murmured against Moses and Aaron in the wilderness:

And*p the children of Israel said unto them, Would to God we had died by the hand of the Lord*s in the land of Egypt, when we sat by the flesh pots, and when we did eat bread to the full; for ye have brought us forth into this wilderness, to kill this whole assembly with hunger.

Then*p said the Lord*s unto Moses, Behold, I will rain bread from heaven for you; and the people shall go out and gather a certain rate every day, that I may prove them, whether they will walk in my law, or no.
And*p it shall come to pass, that on the sixth day they shall prepare that which they bring in; and it shall be twice as much as they gather daily.
And*p Moses and Aaron said unto all the children of Israel, At even, then ye shall know that the Lord*s hath brought you out from the land of Egypt:
And*p in the morning, then ye shall see the glory of the Lord;*s for that he heareth your murmurings against the Lord:*s and what are we, that ye murmur against us?

And*p Moses said, This shall be, when the Lord*s shall give you in the evening flesh to eat, and in the morning bread to the full; for that the Lord*s heareth your murmurings which ye murmur against him: and what are we? your murmurings are not against us, but against the Lord.*s
And*p Moses spake unto Aaron, Say unto all the congregation of the children of Israel, Come near before the Lord:*s for he hath heard your murmurings.
And*p it came to pass, as Aaron spake unto the whole congregation of the children of Israel, that they looked toward the wilderness, and, behold, the glory of the Lord*s appeared in the cloud.
And*p the Lord*s spake unto Moses, saying,

I*p have heard the murmurings of the children of Israel: speak unto them, saying, At even ye shall eat flesh, and in the morning ye shall be filled with bread; and ye shall know that I am the Lord*s your God.
And*p it came to pass, that at even the quails came up, and covered the camp: and in the morning the dew lay round about the host.
And*p when the dew that lay was gone up, behold, upon the face of the wilderness there lay a small round thing, as small as the hoar frost on the ground.
And*p when the children of Israel saw it, they said one to another, It is manna: for they wist not what it was. And Moses said unto them, This is the bread which the Lord*s hath given you to eat.

This*p is the thing which the Lord*s hath commanded, Gather of it every man according to his eating, an omer for every man, according to the number of your persons; take ye every man for them which are in his tents.
And*p the children of Israel did so, and gathered, some more, some less.
And*p when they did mete it with an omer, he that gathered much had nothing over, and he that gathered little had no lack; they gathered every man according to his eating.
And*p Moses said, Let no man leave of it till the morning.
Notwithstanding*p they hearkened not unto Moses; but some of them left of it until the morning, and it bred worms, and stank: and Moses was wroth with them.
And*p they gathered it every morning, every man according to his eating: and when the sun waxed hot, it melted.
And*p it came to pass, that on the sixth day they gathered twice as much bread, two omers for one man: and all the rulers of the congregation came and told Moses.

And*p he said unto them, This is that which the Lord*s hath said, To morrow is the rest of the holy sabbath unto the Lord:*s bake that which ye will bake to day, and seethe that ye will seethe; and that which remaineth over lay up for you to be kept until the morning.
And*p they laid it up till the morning, as Moses bade: and it did not stink, neither was there any worm therein.
And*p Moses said, Eat that to day; for to day is a sabbath unto the Lord:*s to day ye shall not find it in the field.
Six*p days ye shall gather it; but on the seventh day, which is the sabbath, in it there shall be none.
And*p it came to pass, that there went out some of the people on the seventh day for to gather, and they found none.
And*p the Lord*s said unto Moses, How long refuse ye to keep my commandments and my laws?

See,*p for that the Lord*s hath given you the sabbath, therefore he giveth you on the sixth day the bread of two days; abide ye every man in his place, let no man go out of his place on the seventh day.
So*p the people rested on the seventh day.
And*p the house of Israel called the name thereof Manna: and it was like coriander seed, white; and the taste of it was like wafers made with honey.

And*p Moses said, This is the thing which the Lord*s commandeth, Fill an omer of it to be kept for your generations; that they may see the bread wherewith I have fed you in the wilderness, when I brought you forth from the land of Egypt.
And*p Moses said unto Aaron, Take a pot, and put an omer full of manna therein, and lay it up before the Lord,*s to be kept for your generations.
As*p the Lord*s commanded Moses, so Aaron laid it up before the Testimony, to be kept.
And*p the children of Israel did eat manna forty years, until they came to a land inhabited; they did eat manna, until they came unto the borders of the land of Canaan.
Now*p an omer is the tenth part of an ephah.
Exodus 17

And*p all the congregation of the children of Israel journeyed from the wilderness of Sin, after their journeys, according to the commandment of the Lord,*s and pitched in Rephidim: and there was no water for the people to drink.
Wherefore*p the people did chide with Moses, and said, Give us water that we may drink. And Moses said unto them, Why chide ye with me? wherefore do ye tempt the Lord?*s

And*p the people thirsted there for water; and the people murmured against Moses, and said, Wherefore is this that thou hast brought us up out of Egypt, to kill us and our children and our cattle with thirst?
And*p Moses cried unto the Lord,*s saying, What shall I do unto this people? they be almost ready to stone me.
And*p the Lord*s said unto Moses, Go on before the people, and take with thee of the elders of Israel; and thy rod, wherewith thou smotest the river, take in thine hand, and go.

Behold,*p I will stand before thee there upon the rock in Horeb; and thou shalt smite the rock, and there shall come water out of it, that the people may drink. And Moses did so in the sight of the elders of Israel.
And*p he called the name of the place Massah, and Meribah, because of the chiding of the children of Israel, and because they tempted the Lord,*s saying, Is the Lord*s among us, or not?
Then*p came Amalek, and fought with Israel in Rephidim.
And*p Moses said unto Joshua, Choose us out men, and go out, fight with Amalek: to morrow I will stand on the top of the hill with the rod of God in mine hand.
So*p Joshua did as Moses had said to him, and fought with Amalek: and Moses, Aaron, and Hur went up to the top of the hill.
And*p it came to pass, when Moses held up his hand, that Israel prevailed: and when he let down his hand, Amalek prevailed.

But*p Moses' hands were heavy; and they took a stone, and put it under him, and he sat thereon; and Aaron and Hur stayed up his hands, the one on the one side, and the other on the other side; and his hands were steady until the going down of the sun.
And*p Joshua discomfited Amalek and his people with the edge of the sword.
And*p the Lord*s said unto Moses, Write this for a memorial in a book, and rehearse it in the ears of Joshua: for I will utterly put out the remembrance of Amalek from under heaven.
And*p Moses built an altar, and called the name of it Jehovah–nissi:
For*p he said, Because the Lord*s hath sworn that the Lord*s will have war with Amalek from generation to generation.
Exodus 18
When*p Jethro, the priest of Midian, Moses' father in law, heard of all that God had done for Moses, and for Israel his people, and that the Lord*s had brought Israel out of Egypt;
Then*p Jethro, Moses' father in law, took Zipporah, Moses' wife, after he had sent her back,
And*p her two sons; of which the name of the one was Gershom; for he said, I have been an alien in a strange land:
And*p the name of the other was Eliezer; for the God of my father, said he, was mine help, and delivered me from the sword of Pharaoh:
And*p Jethro, Moses' father in law, came with his sons and his wife unto Moses into the wilderness, where he encamped at the mount of God:
And*p he said unto Moses, I thy father in law Jethro am come unto thee, and thy wife, and her two sons with her.
And*p Moses went out to meet his father in law, and did obeisance, and kissed him; and they asked each other of their welfare; and they came into the tent.

And*p Moses told his father in law all that the Lord*s had done unto Pharaoh and to the Egyptians for Israel's sake, and all the travail that had come upon them by the way, and how the Lord*s delivered them.
And*p Jethro rejoiced for all the goodness which the Lord*s had done to Israel, whom he had delivered out of the hand of the Egyptians.
And*p Jethro said, Blessed be the Lord,*s who hath delivered you out of the hand of the Egyptians, and out of the hand of Pharaoh, who hath delivered the people from under the hand of the Egyptians.
Now*p I know that the Lord*s is greater than all gods: for in the thing wherein they dealt proudly he was above them.
And*p Jethro, Moses' father in law, took a burnt offering and sacrifices for God: and Aaron came, and all the elders of Israel, to eat bread with Moses' father in law before God.
And*p it came to pass on the morrow, that Moses sat to judge the people: and the people stood by Moses from the morning unto the evening.

And*p when Moses' father in law saw all that he did to the people, he said, What is this thing that thou doest to the people? why sittest thou thyself alone, and all the people stand by thee from morning unto even?
And*p Moses said unto his father in law, Because the people come unto me to enquire of God:
When*p they have a matter, they come unto me; and I judge between one and another, and I do make them know the statutes of God, and his laws.
And*p Moses' father in law said unto him, The thing that thou doest is not good.
Thou*p wilt surely wear away, both thou, and this people that is with thee: for this thing is too heavy for thee; thou art not able to perform it thyself alone.
Hearken*p now unto my voice, I will give thee counsel, and God shall be with thee: Be thou for the people to God-ward, that thou mayest bring the causes unto God:
And*p thou shalt teach them ordinances and laws, and shalt shew them the way wherein they must walk, and the work that they must do.

Moreover*p thou shalt provide out of all the people able men, such as fear God, men of truth, hating covetousness; and place such over them, to be rulers of thousands, and rulers of hundreds, rulers of fifties, and rulers of tens:

And*p let them judge the people at all seasons: and it shall be, that every great matter they shall bring unto thee, but every small matter they shall judge: so shall it be easier for thyself, and they shall bear the burden with thee.
If*p thou shalt do this thing, and God command thee so, then thou shalt be able to endure, and all this people shall also go to their place in peace.
So*p Moses hearkened to the voice of his father in law, and did all that he had said.
And*p Moses chose able men out of all Israel, and made them heads over the people, rulers of thousands, rulers of hundreds, rulers of fifties, and rulers of tens.
And*p they judged the people at all seasons: the hard causes they brought unto Moses, but every small matter they judged themselves.
And*p Moses let his father in law depart; and he went his way into his own land.
Exodus 19
In*p the third month, when the children of Israel were gone forth out of the land of Egypt, the same day came they into the wilderness of Sinai.
For*p they were departed from Rephidim, and were come to the desert of Sinai, and had pitched in the wilderness; and there Israel camped before the mount.
And*p Moses went up unto God, and the Lord*s called unto him out of the mountain, saying, Thus shalt thou say to the house of Jacob, and tell the children of Israel;
Ye*p have seen what I did unto the Egyptians, and how I bare you on eagles' wings, and brought you unto myself.
Now*p therefore, if ye will obey my voice indeed, and keep my covenant, then ye shall be a peculiar treasure unto me above all people: for all the earth is mine:
And*p ye shall be unto me a kingdom of priests, and an holy nation. These are the words which thou shalt speak unto the children of Israel.
And*p Moses came and called for the elders of the people, and laid before their faces all these words which the Lord*s commanded him.
And*p all the people answered together, and said, All that the Lord*s hath spoken we will do. And Moses returned the words of the people unto the Lord.*s

And*p the Lord*s said unto Moses, Lo, I come unto thee in a thick cloud, that the people may hear when I speak with thee, and believe thee for ever. And Moses told the words of the people unto the Lord.*s
And*p the Lord*s said unto Moses, Go unto the people, and sanctify them to day and to morrow, and let them wash their clothes,
And*p be ready against the third day: for the third day the Lord*s will come down in the sight of all the people upon mount Sinai.

And*p thou shalt set bounds unto the people round about, saying, Take heed to yourselves, that ye go not up into the mount, or touch the border of it: whosoever toucheth the mount shall be surely put to death:
There*p shall not an hand touch it, but he shall surely be stoned, or shot through; whether it be beast or man, it shall not live: when the trumpet soundeth long, they shall come up to the mount.
And*p Moses went down from the mount unto the people, and sanctified the people; and they washed their clothes.
And*p he said unto the people, Be ready against the third day: come not at your wives.

And*p it came to pass on the third day in the morning, that there were thunders and lightnings, and a thick cloud upon the mount, and the voice of the trumpet exceeding loud; so that all the people that was in the camp trembled.
And*p Moses brought forth the people out of the camp to meet with God; and they stood at the nether part of the mount.
And*p mount Sinai was altogether on a smoke, because the Lord*s descended upon it in fire: and the smoke thereof ascended as the smoke of a furnace, and the whole mount quaked greatly.
And*p when the voice of the trumpet sounded long, and waxed louder and louder, Moses spake, and God answered him by a voice.
And*p the Lord*s came down upon mount Sinai, on the top of the mount: and the Lord*s called Moses up to the top of the mount; and Moses went up.
And*p the Lord*s said unto Moses, Go down, charge the people, lest they break through unto the Lord*s to gaze, and many of them perish.
And*p let the priests also, which come near to the Lord,*s sanctify themselves, lest the Lord*s break forth upon them.
And*p Moses said unto the Lord,*s The people cannot come up to mount Sinai: for thou chargedst us, saying, Set bounds about the mount, and sanctify it.

And*p the Lord*s said unto him, Away, get thee down, and thou shalt come up, thou, and Aaron with thee: but let not the priests and the people break through to come up unto the Lord,*s lest he break forth upon them.
So*p Moses went down unto the people, and spake unto them.
Exodus 20
And*p God spake all these words, saying,
I*p am the Lord*s thy God, which have brought thee out of the land of Egypt, out of the house of bondage.
Thou*p shalt have no other gods before me.
Thou*p shalt not make unto thee any graven image, or any likeness of any thing that is in heaven above, or that is in the earth beneath, or that is in the water under the earth:

Thou*p shalt not bow down thyself to them, nor serve them: for I the Lord*s thy God am a jealous God, visiting the iniquity of the fathers upon the children unto the third and fourth generation of them that hate me;
And*p shewing mercy unto thousands of them that love me, and keep my commandments.
Thou*p shalt not take the name of the Lord*s thy God in vain; for the Lord*s will not hold him guiltless that taketh his name in vain.
Remember*p the sabbath day, to keep it holy.
Six*p days shalt thou labour, and do all thy work:

But*p the seventh day is the sabbath of the Lord*s thy God: in it thou shalt not do any work, thou, nor thy son, nor thy daughter, thy manservant, nor thy maidservant, nor thy cattle, nor thy stranger that is within thy gates:
For*p in six days the Lord*s made heaven and earth, the sea, and all that in them is, and rested the seventh day: wherefore the Lord*s blessed the sabbath day, and hallowed it.
Honour*p thy father and thy mother: that thy days may be long upon the land which the Lord*s thy God giveth thee.
Thou*p shalt not kill.
Thou*p shalt not commit adultery.
Thou*p shalt not steal.
Thou*p shalt not bear false witness against thy neighbour.
Thou*p shalt not covet thy neighbour's house, thou shalt not covet thy neighbour's wife, nor his manservant, nor his maidservant, nor his ox, nor his ass, nor any thing that is thy neighbour's.
And*p all the people saw the thunderings, and the lightnings, and the noise of the trumpet, and the mountain smoking: and when the people saw it, they removed, and stood afar off.
And*p they said unto Moses, Speak thou with us, and we will hear: but let not God speak with us, lest we die.
